title: Cat. 110  Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Nov. 1899
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Nov. 1899  
1899  
Monogram PGO: only state  
Title block: only state  
Headpiece Three People, a Mask, a Fox, and a Bird: only state  
Mimeograph in brownish-black ink, with wood-block prints in black ink on cream wove paper; 397 × 513 mm (full sheet); 397 × 256 mm (folded sheet); 32 mm (diameter of printed monogram); 24 × 94 mm (title block); 105 × 187 mm (headpiece)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Mr. and Mrs. Carter H. Harrison Collection, 1948.420  
Guérin 75; Kornfeld 56 (monogram), 57 (title block), and 58 (headpiece)  
For inside and back, see fig. 110.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin produced nine issues of Le sourire (The Smile), his “serious newspaper,” as well as three supplements; this issue is the fourth and did not contain a supplement. Using the new technology of mimeography that he encountered while clerking as a draftsman in Papeete, he created the satirical newspaper for local monthly distribution. The machine that Gauguin used was likely an Edison Mimeograph Model 0. These devices were manufactured in Chicago by the A. B. Dick Company and had only become available in 1897 (see Technical Overview). So popular was the machine, which greatly improved the efficiency of bureaucratic offices, that by the time Gauguin gained access to one in 1899, he described it as “all the rage.” It is likely that this duplicating technology also appealed to the artist on a conceptual level, considering his history of experimentation with various transfer processes.

The format of Le sourire is not immediately intuitive. The unusual orientation of text relative to the folding of the sheets indicates that the journal was intended to be read by turning the pages from left to right. Gauguin hoped to use the mimeograph machine to print images and text simultaneously (see Technical Overview). Unfortunately, the technology had limits that thwarted his aesthetic ambitions; the vignettes sprinkled throughout the text of the August, September, and October 1899 issues were rendered partially illegible due to the broken lines and uneven printing. In this and later issues of the journal, he integrated wood-block prints, such as the headpiece, to improve the clarity of his illustrations. In another copy of the November 1899 issue of Le sourire in the Art Institute’s collection, he used A Pig, a Dwarf, Flowers, and Leaves (cat. 109 [Kornfeld 60 B]) as the headpiece.

For this vignette Gauguin used the back of the same block on which he carved Mahana atua (cat. 80) four years earlier. On the same side, he also carved a second vignette, Fox, Busts of Two Women, and a Rabbit (cat. 120). The block was carved so that the vignettes face each other; they abut along their bottom edges. The commercially available woodblock was manufactured with a series of four screws to hold smaller segments of boxwood together. The voids left by the apertures from this assemblage were appropriated by the artist to add his initials and to inscribe numbers onto his prints. The block is extant, in the collection of the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C. (fig. 110.2).

An impression of Three People, a Mask, a Fox, and a Bird adorns the front page of this issue. The irregularity of the impression appears to be a result of selective adhesion of the ink to the block. An excess of linseed oil is indicated by the reticulated pattern of ink deposition and the strike-through of oil on the verso of the sheet as well as onto the sheet facing it. Here the artist’s signature, carved into the matrix, is faintly legible in the lower left.

The monogram and title block below it on the last page were printed in a thick layer of black ink that contained a significant amount of linseed oil as well. This is evidenced by the golden-brown halos present around the printed lines as well as a significant amount of oil strike-through on the verso and onto the facing the page. The rest of the issue was printed in brownish-black ink applied through a mimeograph stencil. The stencil itself was responsible for the grainy appearance of the text (see Technical Overview).

The paper that Gauguin selected is only slightly higher quality than newsprint. It is a thin, soft, short-fibered paper with a slight texture that is visible in transmitted light. Because the paper was formatted for use with the mimeograph machine and because Gauguin was notoriously low on money and supplies, it is possible that he procured this paper from the office where he worked and where he returned to do his mimeograph printing. This same paper appears again in Gauguin’s later work, including the transfer drawings Woman with a Cat (cat. 123) and Sister of Charity (cat. 125).

397 × 513 mm (full sheet); 397 × 256 mm (folded sheet); 32 mm (diameter of printed monogram); 24 × 94 mm (title block); 105 × 187 mm (headpiece)

There is no conservation documentation in the Art Institute’s files, nor any record of previous conservation treatment.

The issue is in fair condition. It was mended along the edges and central folds but it cannot be determined when this was done.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Maurice Gobin (born 1883), Paris, to Carter H. Harrison (1860–1953), Chicago, June 25, 1948.

Given by Mr. and Mrs. Carter H. Harrison to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 222, cat. 58.

Belinda Thomson, ed., Gauguin: Maker of Myth, exh. cat. (Tate Publishing, 2010), pp. 193, 202, fig. 135.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Center mimeographed in brownish-black ink: Journal Sérieux / Gérant Paul Gauguin Novembre

Inscribed upper left, in graphite: No 2

Signed in wood block, lower left, printed in white-line manner: P. Gauguin

Inscribed lower left, in image, in pen and black ink: Gérant

Inscribed lower right, in image, in pen and black ink: Paul Gauguin

Inscribed along folded edge, to the right of the wood-block print, in graphite: M G. 75

Mimeographed upper center, in brownish-black ink: Journal Sérieux / Gérant Paul Gauguin Novembre

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Gauguin gave his publication the subtitle Journal sérieux for the first four months of its production, but by December of 1899, he changed it to Journal méchant (“wicked newspaper”).

Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, with an introduction by L. G. Bouge, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

For Gauguin’s work in Papeete, see Bengt Danielsson, Gauguin in the South Seas, trans. Reginald Spink (Doubleday, 1964).

“J’ai créé en outre un journal ‘Le Sourire’ autographié Système Edison, qui fait fureur” (I have also created a newspaper, The Smile, using the Edison printing system, which is all the rage). Gauguin to Monfreid, Dec. 1899, in Lettres de Gauguin à Daniel de Monfreid, ed. Annie Joly-Segalen, introduction by Victor Segalen (G. Falaize, 1950), p. 151, no. 59. Translation by the authors.

For more on Gauguin’s experiments with transfer techniques, see Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44. See also Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: Monotypes, exh. cat. (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1973).

Receipt from Maurice Gobin, June 25, 1948, six pages from “Le Sourire,” sold to Mr. Carter H. Harrison, curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 110 Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Nov. 1899.

fig. 110.2 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Left, Two Title Pages for “Le sourire,” verso, in or after 1895. Right, Mahana atua, recto, 1894/95. Woodcut block; 20 × 28 cm (7 7/8 × 11 in.). National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., Rosenwald Collection, 1943.3.1726.b, a.

fig. 110.1 Inside and back of Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Nov. 1899. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.420.

</section>
